coredata.dc:title: Dynamic branch prediction and control speculation
coredata.prism:publicationName: International Journal of High Performance Systems Architecture

abstract.ce:para: Branch prediction schemes have become an integral part of today’s superscalar processors. They are one of the key issues in enhancing the performance of processors. Pipeline stalls due to conditional branches are one of the most significant impediments to realise the performance potential of superscalar processors. Many schemes for branch prediction, that can effectively and accurately predict the outcome of branch instructions have been proposed. In this paper, an overview of some dynamic branch prediction schemes for superscalar processors are presented. © 2007 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2018 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

citation-title.titletext: Dynamic branch prediction and control speculation

affiliation.organization: Faculty of Computer and Information Science

abstract.ce:para: Branch prediction schemes have become an integral part of today’s superscalar processors. They are one of the key issues in enhancing the performance of processors. Pipeline stalls due to conditional branches are one of the most significant impediments to realise the performance potential of superscalar processors. Many schemes for branch prediction, that can effectively and accurately predict the outcome of branch instructions have been proposed. In this paper, an overview of some dynamic branch prediction schemes for superscalar processors are presented. © 2007 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.

ref-info.ref-text: A variation of the BTB that was popular for older processors without on-chip I-caches is to store one or more target instructions additionally to the target address

reference.ref-fulltext: A variation of the BTB that was popular for older processors without on-chip I-caches is to store one or more target instructions additionally to the target address.

ref-info.ref-text: Pan et al. (1992) used the terms ‘branch prediction table’ instead of ‘PHT’ and ‘m-bit shift register’ instead of ‘BHR’

reference.ref-fulltext: Pan et al. (1992) used the terms ‘branch prediction table’ instead of ‘PHT’ and ‘m-bit shift register’ instead of ‘BHR’.

ref-info.ref-text: The GAg scheme is called the ‘degenerate case’ of the correlation scheme by Pan et al. (1992)

reference.ref-fulltext: The GAg scheme is called the ‘degenerate case’ of the correlation scheme by Pan et al. (1992).

ref-info.ref-text: The PAp predictor is mainly of theoretical interest, because the variable numbers of BHRs and PHTs cause implementation problems

reference.ref-fulltext: The PAp predictor is mainly of theoretical interest, because the variable numbers of BHRs and PHTs cause implementation problems.

ref-info.ref-text: Prediction accuracy measured for SPECint95 or OLTP (online transaction processing) programes is much lower than for SPEC89 benchmarks (see Table 1)

reference.ref-fulltext: Prediction accuracy measured for SPECint95 or OLTP (online transaction processing) programes is much lower than for SPEC89 benchmarks (see Table 1).

ref-info.ref-text: Called a bimodal predictor by McFarling (1993)

reference.ref-fulltext: Called a bimodal predictor by McFarling (1993).

ref-info.ref-text: Called a local predictor by McFarling, per-address scheme in Yeh and Patt’s nomenclature

reference.ref-fulltext: Called a local predictor by McFarling, per-address scheme in Yeh and Patt’s nomenclature.
